Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Broadening Participation for STEM Women of Color

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Fielding Graduate University, in partnership with the Society of STEM Women of Color, Inc., proposes to enhance and implement the STEM Women of Color Conclave as a Broadening Participation Workshop series that will facilitate the preparation of a cadre of its participants for academic leadership roles. GPRA Strategic Management, Inc. (GPRASMi) will serve as the collaborative organizational partner in implementing the proposed Conclave Workshops. This effort will foster a strategic collaboration and provide access to formal postgraduate training in leadership studies. The overall goal of this effort is to increase the representation of STEM women of color in academic leadership positions by enhancing the quality of the leadership development experience. The proposed Conclave Workshops will heighten the profile of STEM women faculty of color who, in turn, will constitute a powerful knowledge network for broadening participation through effective academic leadership. As a long-term outcome, the proposed leadership development experience for women of color is likely to yield a cadre of academic leaders with the acumen needed to address the shifting demands of higher education, and the cultural sensitivity to yield academic success and better STEM career outcomes, particularly among underrepresented minorities. As such, the proposed Workshops will extend beyond the leadership capacity of its participants to the thousands of underrepresented minority students with whom they will interact.

The proposed project will enhance the leadership development experience for women of color who provide the kind of academic and psychosocial support for underrepresented minority students that leads to better STEM learning outcomes by: 1) convening broadening participation workshops focused on leadership development for STEM women of color; and 2) providing access to opportunities to earn continuing education credits as credentials necessary for acquiring legitimacy in and contributing to STEM academic leadership. The specific objectives are: 1) to convene a two-day Broadening Participation Workshop: National Conclave for STEM Women of Color; and 2) to provide access to continuing education (CE) credits for Conclave participants. This project will contribute to redefining higher education leadership to meaningfully include an awareness of, affinity for, and sensitivity to the academic and psychosocial needs of underrepresented minority students, thereby broadening participation. Collectively, these efforts are expected to impact a network of thousands of STEM higher education reformers committed to diversifying STEM faculty, as well as a wider pool of faculty and academic administrators, from all disciplines, who are committed to recruiting and retaining STEM women faculty of color.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To date, the Conclave has been successful in building a national network of STEM women of color who now comprise an interpretive community with the cultural authority necessary to fully define and contextualize leadership for broadening participation. As such, this venue is now poised to meaningfully address shortages and shortcomings in academic leadership, particularly
as they relate to lack of overall quality and diversity in the leadership development experience.This has been accomplished through two major objectives. They include:


1. Developing a strategic collaboration between the Marie Fielder Center of Fielding Graduate University and the Society of STEM Women of Color, Inc., to convene broadening participation workshops focused on leadership development for STEM women of color; and

2. Providing access to opportunities to earn continuing education credits as credentials necessary for acquiring legitimacy in and contributing to STEM academic leadership.

OBJECTIVE 1: Convene a Broadening Participation Workshop: National Conclave for STEM Women of Color


The Conclave Workshop was structured to accommodate two days of programming.The Workshop was convened at the Turf Valley Conference Center in Ellicott City, MD.   Participants were solicited from among several email listservs that, collectively, include nearly 400 women of color in the academic STEM disciplines. Additionally, the  workshop leveraged the institutional and organizational websites and networks of the project partners, as well as those of its Committee of Advisors, to ensure that a broad
representation of women of color in the academic STEM disciplines was reached.

The agenda was constructed in a way that suggested that women at
the intersection of race and gender comprise a dominant culture in the academy. Elements of the agenda was shaped by and tailored to the lived experiences of STEM women of color, particularly as it relates to ascendancy and persistence in leadership positions

Culturally competent speakers addressed the audience in creative and highly interactive ways that were simultaneously enlightening and empowering, as opposed to defeating and merely informative.

Thought Mapping Assemblies were implemented in an effort to support a healthy identity and world view for STEM women of color. These intensive, informal sessions were facilitated by nationally renowned experts. Expert facilitators  offered participants multi-disciplinary ways of examining various professional, physical, and psychological domains of leadership including, but not limited to: emotional intelligence, negotiation, and conflict resolution.

OBJECTIVE 2: Provide Access to Continuing Education (CE) Credits

A widely accepted model for continuing education, which is mirrored in the structure of Fielding Graduate University and its continuing education programs, is comprised of three primary modes of action that include: 1) reading, 2) reflection, and 3) audit (Stanley, et al., 1993). For the
Conclave Workshops, the reading component of a continuing education opportunity was achieved as a result of Fielding’s requirement that all speakers, including those who were selected from among its own faculty, provide specific learning objectives and relevant readings and educational materials for participants prior to registration. 

Fielding Graduate University offered continuing education credits
to Conclave participants. Specifically, one unit of continuing education credit was offered for each hour of participation in workshop programming. Therefore, because the Conclave Leadership Academy was comprised of 10 (ten) hours of programming, all participants were eligible to earn a total of 10
(ten) CE credits.

As a long-term outcome, the leadership development experience for women of color is likely to yield a cadre of academic leaders with the acumen needed to address the shifting demands of higher education, and the cultural sensitivity to yield academic success and better STEM career outcomes, particularly among underrepresented minorities (Bettinger & Long, 2005). As such, the broader impact of the Workshops has extended beyond the leadership capacity of its participants to the thousands of underrepresented minority students with whom they will interact.
